children.value: This demo shows how to use a simple
behaviour to solve a non-linear sationary heat transfer equation with
Description of the non-linear constitutive heat transfer law

children.label: Description of the non-linear constitutive heat transfer law

children.value:
The thermal material is described by the following non linear Fourier
Law:

children.html: j=−k(T) ∇T\mathbf{j}=-k\left(T\right)\,\mathbf{\nabla} Tj=−k(T)∇T
j\mathbf{j}j
∇T\mathbf{\nabla} T∇T

children.value: The thermal conductivity is assumed to be given by:

children.html: k(T)=1A+B Tk\left(T\right)={\displaystyle \frac{\displaystyle 1}{\displaystyle A+B\,T}}k(T)=A+BT1​

children.value:
This expression accounts for the phononic contribution to the thermal
conductivity.

As discussed below, the consistent linearisation of the heat transfer
equilibrium requires to compute:

children.html: ∂j∂∇T{\displaystyle \frac{\displaystyle \partial \mathbf{j}}{\displaystyle \partial \mathbf{\nabla} T}}∂∇T∂j​

children.value: of the heat flux with respect to the temperature gradient.

children.html: ∂j∂∇T{\displaystyle \frac{\displaystyle \partial \mathbf{j}}{\displaystyle \partial \mathbf{\nabla} T}}∂∇T∂j​
∂j∂∇T=−k(T) I{\displaystyle \frac{\displaystyle \partial \mathbf{j}}{\displaystyle \partial \mathbf{\nabla} T}}=-k\left(T\right)\,I∂∇T∂j​=−k(T)I
∂j∂T{\displaystyle \frac{\displaystyle \partial \mathbf{j}}{\displaystyle \partial T}}∂T∂j​

children.value: of the heat flux with respect to the temperature.

children.html: ∂j∂T{\displaystyle \frac{\displaystyle \partial \mathbf{j}}{\displaystyle \partial T}}∂T∂j​

∂j∂T=−∂k(T)∂T ∇T=B k2 ∇T{\displaystyle \frac{\displaystyle \partial \mathbf{j}}{\displaystyle \partial T}}=-{\displaystyle \frac{\displaystyle \partial k\left(T\right)}{\displaystyle \partial T}}\,\mathbf{\nabla} T=B\,k^{2}\,\mathbf{\nabla} T∂T∂j​=−∂T∂k(T)​∇T=Bk2∇T

children.value: Choice of the the domain specific language

children.label: Choice of the the domain specific language

children.value:
file is handled by a domain specific language (DSL), which
aims at providing the most suitable abstraction for a particular choice
of behaviour and integration algorithm. See
for a list of the available DSLs.
The name of DSL’s handling generic behaviours ends with

. The first part of a DSL’s name is related to the
integration algorithm used.

In the case of this non linear transfer behaviour, the heat flux is
explicitly computed from the temperature and the temperature gradient.
The

The following lines define the name of the behaviour, the name of the
author and the date of its writing:

Generic behaviours relate pairs of gradients and fluxes. Gradients and
fluxes are declared independently but the first declared gradient is
assumed to be conjugated with the first declared fluxes and so on…
The temperature gradient is declared as follows (note that Unicode characters are supported):

.
This is helpful for the calling code.
After this declaration, the following variables will be defined:
at the beginning of the time step.
The increment of the temperature gradient
The heat flux is then declared as follows:

will be the heat flux at the end of
the time step.

By default, the derivatives of the gradients with respect to the fluxes
are declared. Thus the variable

However, as discussed in the next section, the consistent linearisation
of the thermal equilibrium requires to return the derivate of the heat
flux with respect to the increment of the temperature (or equivalently
with respect to the temperature at the end of the time step).

coefficients that appears in the definition of the
thermal conductivity are declared as parameters:

Parameters are stored globally and can be modified from the calling
solver or from
in the case of the coupling with
A local variable is accessible in each code blocks.
Here, we declare the thermal conductivity

as a local variable in
order to be able to compute its value during the behaviour integration
and to reuse this value when computing the tangent operator.

The behaviour integration is straightforward: one starts to compute the
temperature at the end of the time step, then we compute the thermal
conductivity (at the end of the time step) and the heat flux using the
temperature gradient (at the end of the time step).
The computation of the tangent operator blocks is equally simple:
We consider a rectanglar domain with imposed temperatures
) on the left (resp. right) boundaries. We want to solve for the temperature field

children.html: P1P^1P1

children.value: -interpolation. We initialize the temperature at value

import numpy as np
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
import ufl
from mpi4py import MPI
from dolfinx import fem, mesh
from dolfinx.cpp.nls.petsc import NewtonSolver
from dolfinx_materials.quadrature_map import QuadratureMap
from dolfinx_materials.solvers import NonlinearMaterialProblem
from dolfinx_materials.material.mfront import MFrontMaterial
import os


current_path = os.getcwd()

length = 30e-3
width = 5.4e-3
domain = mesh.create_rectangle(MPI.COMM_WORLD, [(0.0, 0.0), (length, width)], [100, 10])

V = fem.functionspace(domain, ("CG", 1))
T = fem.Function(V, name="Temperature")


def left(x):
    return np.isclose(x[0], 0)


def right(x):
    return np.isclose(x[0], length)


Tl = 300.0
Tr = 800.0
T.x.petsc_vec.set(Tl)

left_dofs = fem.locate_dofs_geometrical(V, left)
right_dofs = fem.locate_dofs_geometrical(V, right)

bcs = [fem.dirichletbc(Tl, left_dofs, V), fem.dirichletbc(Tr, right_dofs, V)]
class for describing the material behaviour. The first argument corresponds to the path where material librairies have been compiled, the second correspond to the name of the behaviour (declared with
). Finally, the modelling hypothesis is specified (default behaviour is
as a Gradient variable, with its associated Flux called
’s gradient and flux names, as well as the different tangent operator blocks which have been defined, namely

print(material.gradients)
print(material.fluxes)

print(["d{}_d{}".format(*t) for t in material.tangent_blocks])
We now define the non-linear residual form that we want to solve. After defining test and trial functions, we instantiate the

object. We must provide the requested quadrature degree which will control the number of quadrature points used in each cell to compute the non-linear constitutive law. Here, we specify a quadrature of degree 2 (i.e. 3 Gauss points for a triangular element).

T_ = ufl.TestFunction(V)
dT = ufl.TrialFunction(V)

deg_quad = 2
qmap = QuadratureMap(domain, deg_quad, material)
behaviour implicitly declares the temperature as an external state variable called
. We must therefore associate this external state variable to a known mechanical field. This can be achieved explicitly using the
For problems in which the temperature only acts as a parameter (no jacobian blocks with respect to the temperature), the temperature can be automatically registered as a constant value (

children.html: 293.15 K293.15 \text{ K}293.15 K

children.value: by default) or to any other (
Finally, we need to associate to
gradient object the corresponding UFL expression as a function of the unknown field
. To do so, we use the
We are now in position of defining the nonlinear variational formulation corresponding to the stationary nonlinear heat transfer. Without any external loading, the nonlinear residual reads as:

children.html: F(T^)=∫Ωj⋅∇T^dx=0∀T^F(\widehat{T}) = \int_\Omega \mathbf{j}\cdot \nabla \widehat{T} \text{dx} = 0 \quad \forall \widehat{T}F(T)=∫Ω​j⋅∇Tdx=0∀T
j\mathbf{j}j

children.value: as a flux. The latter is a
function space (no interpolation is possible). Note that the integration measure must match the chosen quadrature scheme and quadrature degree. It is provided here as
function works similarly to the standard
function except that it will also differentiate the heat flux. From the two tangent operator blocks
, it will automatically be deduced that the heat flux

children.html: j\mathbf{j}j

children.value: is a function of both the temperature gradient

children.html: g=∇T\mathbf{g}=\nabla Tg=∇T
j=j(g,T)\mathbf{j}=\mathbf{j}(\mathbf{g}, T)j=j(g,T)

children.value: . Hence, the computed Jacobian form will be:

children.html: J(T^,T∗)=∫Ω∇T^⋅(∂j∂g⋅∇T∗+∂j∂T⋅T∗)dxJ(\widehat{T},T^*) = \int_{\Omega} \nabla \widehat{T}\cdot\left(\dfrac{\partial \mathbf{j}}{\partial \mathbf{g}}\cdot \nabla T^*+\dfrac{\partial \mathbf{j}}{\partial T}\cdot T^*\right) \text{dx}J(T,T∗)=∫Ω​∇T⋅(∂g∂j​⋅∇T∗+∂T∂j​⋅T∗)dx

children.value: The resulting nonlinear problem is managed by the
class. It is solved using a Newton non-linear solver. The
method returns the converged status and the number of Newton iterations.

j = qmap.fluxes["HeatFlux"]

F = ufl.dot(j, ufl.grad(T_)) * qmap.dx
Jac = qmap.derivative(F, T, dT)

problem = NonlinearMaterialProblem(qmap, F, Jac, T, bcs)

newton = NewtonSolver(MPI.COMM_WORLD)

converged, it = problem.solve(newton)

# Problem is weakly nonlinear, it should converge in a few iterations
assert converged and it < 10
We finally check that the thermal conductivity coefficient

children.html: kkk

children.value: , computed from the ratio between the horizontal heat flux and temperature gradient matches the temperature-dependent expressions implemented in the

j_vals = j.x.array
g_vals = qmap.gradients["TemperatureGradient"].function.x.array
k_gauss = -j_vals[::2] / g_vals[::2]
T_gauss = qmap.external_state_variables["Temperature"].function.x.array
A = material.get_parameter("A")
B = material.get_parameter("B")
k_ref = 1 / (A + B * T_gauss)
plt.plot(T_gauss, k_gauss, "o", label="FE")
plt.plot(T_gauss, k_ref, ".", label="ref")
plt.xlabel(r"Temperature $T\: (K)$")
plt.ylabel(r"Thermal conductivity $k\: (W.m^{-1}.K^{-1})$")
plt.legend()
plt.show()
